    % For linebreaks inside Verbatim environment from package fancyvrb.
    \makeatletter
        \newbox\Wrappedcontinuationbox
        \newbox\Wrappedvisiblespacebox
        \newcommand*\Wrappedvisiblespace {\textcolor{red}{\textvisiblespace}}
        \newcommand*\Wrappedcontinuationsymbol {\textcolor{red}{\llap{\tiny$\m@th\hookrightarrow$}}}
        \newcommand*\Wrappedcontinuationindent {3ex }
        \newcommand*\Wrappedafterbreak {\kern\Wrappedcontinuationindent\copy\Wrappedcontinuationbox}
        % Take advantage of the already applied Pygments mark-up to insert
        % potential linebreaks for TeX processing.
        %        {, <, #, %, $, ' and ": go to next line.
        %        _, }, ^, &, >, - and ~: stay at end of broken line.
        % Use of \textquotesingle for straight quote.
        \newcommand*\Wrappedbreaksatspecials {%
            \def\PYGZus{\discretionary{\char`\_}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\_}}%
            \def\PYGZob{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\char`\{}{\char`\{}}%
            \def\PYGZcb{\discretionary{\char`\}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\}}}%
            \def\PYGZca{\discretionary{\char`\^}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\^}}%
            \def\PYGZam{\discretionary{\char`\&}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\&}}%
            \def\PYGZlt{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\char`\<}{\char`\<}}%
            \def\PYGZgt{\discretionary{\char`\>}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\>}}%
            \def\PYGZsh{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\char`\#}{\char`\#}}%
            \def\PYGZpc{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\char`\%}{\char`\%}}%
            \def\PYGZdl{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\char`\$}{\char`\$}}%
            \def\PYGZhy{\discretionary{\char`\-}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\-}}%
            \def\PYGZsq{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\textquotesingle}{\textquotesingle}}%
            \def\PYGZdq{\discretionary{}{\Wrappedafterbreak\char`\"}{\char`\"}}%
            \def\PYGZti{\discretionary{\char`\~}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\char`\~}}%
        }
        % Some characters . , ; ? ! / are not pygmentized.
        % This macro makes them "active" and they will insert potential linebreaks
        \newcommand*\Wrappedbreaksatpunct {%
            \lccode`\~`\.\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\.}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\.}}}%
            \lccode`\~`\,\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\,}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\,}}}%
            \lccode`\~`\;\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\;}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\;}}}%
            \lccode`\~`\:\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\:}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\:}}}%
            \lccode`\~`\?\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\?}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\?}}}%
            \lccode`\~`\!\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\!}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\!}}}%
            \lccode`\~`\/\lowercase{\def~}{\discretionary{\hbox{\char`\/}}{\Wrappedafterbreak}{\hbox{\char`\/}}}%
            \catcode`\.\active
            \catcode`\,\active
            \catcode`\;\active
            \catcode`\:\active
            \catcode`\?\active
            \catcode`\!\active
            \catcode`\/\active
            \lccode`\~`\~
        }

    \let\OriginalVerbatim=\Verbatim
    \makeatletter
    \renewcommand{\Verbatim}[1][1]{%
        %\parskip\z@skip
        \sbox\Wrappedcontinuationbox {\Wrappedcontinuationsymbol}%
        \sbox\Wrappedvisiblespacebox {\FV@SetupFont\Wrappedvisiblespace}%
        \def\FancyVerbFormatLine ##1{\hsize\linewidth
            \vtop{\raggedright\hyphenpenalty\z@\exhyphenpenalty\z@
                \doublehyphendemerits\z@\finalhyphendemerits\z@
                \strut ##1\strut}%
        }%
        % If the linebreak is at a space, the latter will be displayed as visible
        % space at end of first line, and a continuation symbol starts next line.
        % Stretch/shrink are however usually zero for typewriter font.
        \def\FV@Space {%
            \nobreak\hskip\z@ plus\fontdimen3\font minus\fontdimen4\font
            \discretionary{\copy\Wrappedvisiblespacebox}{\Wrappedafterbreak}
            {\kern\fontdimen2\font}%
        }%

        % Allow breaks at special characters using \PYG... macros.
        \Wrappedbreaksatspecials
        % Breaks at punctuation characters . , ; ? ! and / need catcode=\active
        \OriginalVerbatim[#1,codes*=\Wrappedbreaksatpunct]%
    }

<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
<div class="mw-body-content" id="mw-content-text"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-
parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a
class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Poster\_-
\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg"><img alt="A screencap of the title card from the
trailer of Gone with the Wind." class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000"
data-file-width="1299" decoding="async" height="339"
src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Poster\_-
\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg/220px-Poster\_-\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg"
srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Poster\_-
\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg/330px-Poster\_-\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg 1.5x,
//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Poster\_-
\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg/440px-Poster\_-\_Gone\_With\_the\_Wind\_01.jpg 2x"
width="220"/></a><figcaption><i><a href="/wiki/Gone\_with\_the\_Wind\_(film)"
title="Gone with the Wind (film)">Gone with the Wind</a></i> held the record of
highest-grossing film for twenty-five years and, adjusted for inflation, has
earned more than any other film.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Film" title="Film">Films</a> generate income from several
revenue streams, including <a href="/wiki/Movie\_theater" title="Movie
theater">theatrical exhibition</a>, <a href="/wiki/Home\_video" title="Home
video">home video</a>, <a href="/wiki/Broadcasting\_rights" title="Broadcasting
rights">television broadcast rights</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Merchandising"
title="Merchandising">merchandising</a>. However, theatrical <a
href="/wiki/Box\_office" title="Box office">box-office</a> earnings are the
primary metric for trade publications in assessing the success of a film, mostly
because of the availability of the data compared to sales figures for home video
and broadcast rights, but also because of historical practice. Included on the
list are charts of the top box-office earners (ranked by both the <a class="mw-
redirect" href="/wiki/Real\_versus\_nominal\_value\_(economics)" title="Real versus
nominal value (economics)">nominal and real value</a> of their revenue), a chart
of high-grossing films by calendar year, a timeline showing the transition of
the highest-grossing film record, and a chart of the highest-grossing film
franchises and series. All charts are ranked by international theatrical box-
office performance where possible, excluding income derived from home video,
broadcasting rights, and merchandise.
</p><p>Traditionally, <a href="/wiki/War\_film" title="War film">war films</a>,
<a href="/wiki/Musical\_film" title="Musical film">musicals</a>, and <a
class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List\_of\_historical\_drama\_films" title="List of
historical drama films">historical dramas</a> have been the most popular genres,
but <a href="/wiki/Film\_franchise" title="Film franchise">franchise films</a>
have been among the best performers of the 21st century. There is strong
interest in the <a href="/wiki/Superhero\_film" title="Superhero film">superhero
genre</a>, with eleven films in the <a href="/wiki/Marvel\_Cinematic\_Universe"
title="Marvel Cinematic Universe">Marvel Cinematic Universe</a> featuring among
the nominal top-earners. The most successful superhero film, <i><a
href="/wiki/Avengers:\_Endgame" title="Avengers: Endgame">Avengers:
Endgame</a></i>, is also the second-highest-grossing film on the nominal
earnings chart, and there are four films in total based on the <i><a
href="/wiki/Avengers\_(comics)" title="Avengers (comics)">Avengers</a></i> comic
books charting in the top twenty. Other <a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/List\_of\_films\_based\_on\_Marvel\_Comics" title="List of films based on
Marvel Comics">Marvel Comics adaptations</a> have also had success with the
<i><a href="/wiki/Spider-Man\_in\_film" title="Spider-Man in film">Spider-
Man</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/X-Men\_(film\_series)" title="X-Men (film
series)">X-Men</a></i> properties, while films based on <i><a
href="/wiki/Batman\_in\_film" title="Batman in film">Batman</a></i> and <i><a
href="/wiki/Superman\_in\_film" title="Superman in film">Superman</a></i> from <a
href="/wiki/DC\_Comics" title="DC Comics">DC Comics</a> have generally performed
well. <i><a href="/wiki/Star\_Wars" title="Star Wars">Star Wars</a></i> is also
represented in the nominal earnings chart with five films, while the <i><a
href="/wiki/Jurassic\_Park" title="Jurassic Park">Jurassic Park</a></i> franchise
features prominently. Although the nominal earnings chart is dominated by films
adapted from pre-existing properties and sequels, it is headed by <i><a
href="/wiki/Avatar\_(2009\_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">Avatar</a></i>, which
is an original work. Animated family films have performed consistently well,
with <a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/List\_of\_Disney\_theatrical\_animated\_features" title="List of Disney
theatrical animated features">Disney films</a> enjoying lucrative re-releases
prior to the home-video era. Disney also enjoyed later success with films such
as <i><a href="/wiki/Frozen\_(2013\_film)" title="Frozen (2013
film)">Frozen</a></i> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frozen\_II"
title="Frozen II">its sequel</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Zootopia"
title="Zootopia">Zootopia</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The\_Lion\_King"
title="The Lion King">The Lion King</a></i> (along with <a
href="/wiki/The\_Lion\_King\_(2019\_film)" title="The Lion King (2019 film)">its
computer-animated remake</a>), as well as its <a
href="/wiki/List\_of\_Pixar\_films" title="List of Pixar films">Pixar</a> division,
of which <i><a href="/wiki/Inside\_Out\_2" title="Inside Out 2">Inside Out
2</a></i> (the <a href="/wiki/List\_of\_highest-grossing\_animated\_films"
title="List of highest-grossing animated films">highest-grossing animated
film</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Incredibles\_2" title="Incredibles 2">Incredibles
2</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Toy\_Story\_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story
3</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Toy\_Story\_4" title="Toy Story 4">4</a></i> have
been the best performers. Beyond Disney and Pixar animation, the <i><a
href="/wiki/Despicable\_Me" title="Despicable Me">Despicable Me</a></i> and <i><a
href="/wiki/Shrek\_(franchise)" title="Shrek (franchise)">Shrek</a></i> series
have met with the most success.
</p><p>While <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> has
eroded the achievements of most films from the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, there
are franchises originating from that period that are still active. Besides the
<i>Star Wars</i> and <i>Superman</i> franchises, <i><a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/James\_Bond\_in\_film" title="James Bond in film">James Bond</a></i>
and <i><a href="/wiki/Godzilla\_(franchise)" title="Godzilla
(franchise)">Godzilla</a></i> films are still being released periodically; all
four are among the highest-grossing franchises. Some of the older films that
held the record of highest-grossing film still have respectable grosses by
today's standards, but no longer compete numerically against today's top-earners
in an era of much higher individual ticket prices. When those prices are
adjusted for inflation, however, then <i><a
href="/wiki/Gone\_with\_the\_Wind\_(film)" title="Gone with the Wind (film)">Gone
with the Wind</a></i>—which was the highest-grossing film outright for twenty-
five years—is still the highest-grossing film of all time. All grosses on the
list are expressed in <a href="/wiki/United\_States\_dollar" title="United States
dollar">U.S. dollars</a> at their nominal value, except where stated otherwise.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output
.toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-
parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5
.toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output
.toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul\{display:none\}</style><div class="toclimit-2"><meta
property="mw:PageProp/toc"/></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Highest-grossing\_films">Highest-
grossing films</h2></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a
class="mw-file-description"
href="/wiki/File:James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg"><img alt="A portrait of a
middle aged man with greying hair." class="mw-file-element" data-file-
height="2782" data-file-width="2046" decoding="async" height="231" src="//upload
.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg/1
70px-James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedi
a/commons/thumb/f/fe/James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg/255px-
James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/common
s/thumb/f/fe/James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg/340px-
James\_Cameron\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a><figcaption>Three of the
four highest-grossing films, including <i>Avatar</i> at the top, were written
and directed by <a href="/wiki/James\_Cameron" title="James Cameron">James
Cameron</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>With a worldwide box-office gross of over \$2.9 billion, <i>Avatar</i> is
proclaimed to be the "highest-grossing" film, but such claims usually refer to
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Movie\_theatre" title="Movie
theatre">theatrical</a> revenues only and do not take into account <a
href="/wiki/Home\_video" title="Home video">home video</a> and <a
href="/wiki/Television" title="Television">television</a> income, which can form
a significant portion of a film's earnings. Once revenue from home entertainment
is factored in, it is not immediately clear which film is the most successful.
<i><a href="/wiki/Titanic\_(1997\_film)" title="Titanic (1997
film)">Titanic</a></i> earned \$1.2 billion from <a href="/wiki/Video"
title="Video">video</a> and <a href="/wiki/DVD-Video" title="DVD-Video">DVD</a>
sales and rentals,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-titanic-sales\_1-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-titanic-sales-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> in addition to the \$2.2 billion it
grossed in theaters. While complete sales data are not available for
<i>Avatar</i>, it earned \$345 million from the sale of sixteen million DVD and
<a href="/wiki/Blu-ray" title="Blu-ray">Blu-ray</a> units in North America,<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-2"><a href="\#cite\_note-2"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and ultimately
sold a total of thirty million DVD and Blu-ray units worldwide.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-3"><a href="\#cite\_note-3"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After home video
income is accounted for, both films have earned over \$3 billion each. Television
<a href="/wiki/Broadcasting" title="Broadcasting">broadcast</a> rights will also
substantially add to a film's earnings, with a film often earning the equivalent
of as much as 20–25\% of its theatrical box office for two television runs, on
top of <a href="/wiki/Pay-per-view" title="Pay-per-view">pay-per-view</a>
revenues;<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-4"><a href="\#cite\_note-4"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
<i>Titanic</i> earned a further \$55 million from the <a href="/wiki/NBC"
title="NBC">NBC</a> and <a href="/wiki/HBO" title="HBO">HBO</a> broadcast
rights,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-titanic-sales\_1-1"><a
href="\#cite\_note-titanic-sales-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> equating to about 9\% of its North
American gross.
</p><p>When a film is highly exploitable as a commercial property, its ancillary
revenues can dwarf its income from direct film sales.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-5"><a href="\#cite\_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The Lion King</i> (1994) earned over
\$2 billion in box-office and home video sales,<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-titanic-sales\_1-2"><a href="\#cite\_note-titanic-sales-1"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but
this pales in comparison to the \$8 billion earned at box offices around the
world by <a href="/wiki/The\_Lion\_King\_(musical)" title="The Lion King
(musical)">the stage adaptation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-6"><a
href="\#cite\_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Merchandising"
title="Merchandising">Merchandising</a> can be extremely lucrative too: <i>The
Lion King</i> also sold \$3 billion of merchandise,<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-7"><a href="\#cite\_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while Pixar's <i><a
href="/wiki/Cars\_(film)" title="Cars (film)">Cars</a></i>—which earned
\$462 million in theatrical revenues and was only a modest hit by comparison to
other <a href="/wiki/List\_of\_Pixar\_films" title="List of Pixar films">Pixar
films</a><sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-8"><a href="\#cite\_note-8"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup>—generated global merchandise sales of over
\$8 billion in the five years after its 2006 release.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-9"><a href="\#cite\_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-10"><a href="\#cite\_note-10"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Pixar had
another huge hit with <i>Toy Story 3</i>, which generated almost \$10 billion in
merchandise retail sales in addition to the \$1 billion it earned at the box
office.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-11"><a href="\#cite\_note-11"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On this chart, films are ranked by the revenues from theatrical
exhibition at their nominal value, along with the highest positions they
attained. Six films in total have grossed in excess of \$2 billion worldwide,
with <i>Avatar</i> ranked in the top position. All of the films have had a
theatrical run (including re-releases) in the 21st century, and films that have
not played during this period do not appear on the chart because of ticket-price
inflation, population size and ticket purchasing trends not being considered.
</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Highest-
grossing\_films\_adjusted\_for\_inflation">Highest-grossing films adjusted for
inflation</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236090951">.mw-parser-output
.hatnote\{font-style:italic\}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote\{padding-
left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em\}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i\{font-
style:normal\}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote\{margin-top:-0.5em\}@media
print\{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote\{display:none!important\}\}</style><div
class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a
href="/wiki/List\_of\_highest-
grossing\_films\_in\_the\_United\_States\_and\_Canada\#Adjusted\_for\_ticket-
price\_inflation" title="List of highest-grossing films in the United States and
Canada">List of highest-grossing films in the United States and Canada
§ Adjusted for ticket-price inflation</a>, and <a
href="/wiki/List\_of\_films\_by\_box\_office\_admissions" title="List of films by box
office admissions">List of films by box office admissions</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a
class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg"><img
alt="A map of the world with different regions colored in correlating to
inflation rates" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1314" data-file-
width="2560" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia
/commons/thumb/5/53/World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg/220px-
World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/comm
ons/thumb/5/53/World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg/330px-
World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons
/thumb/5/53/World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg/440px-
World\_Inflation\_rate\_2017.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a><figcaption>Inflation
rates around the world vary, complicating inflation
adjustment.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Because of the long-term effects of <a href="/wiki/Inflation"
title="Inflation">inflation</a>, notably the significant increase of movie
theater ticket prices, the list unadjusted for inflation gives far more weight
to later films.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Bialik\_(2010-1-29)\_104-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Bialik\_(2010-1-29)-104"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The unadjusted
list, while commonly found in the press, is therefore largely meaningless for
comparing films widely separated in time, as many films from earlier eras will
never appear on a modern unadjusted list, despite achieving higher commercial
success when adjusted for price increases.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
Pincus-Roth\_(2009)\_105-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Pincus-Roth\_(2009)-105"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> To
compensate for the devaluation of the currency, some charts make adjustments for
inflation, but not even this practice fully addresses the issue, since ticket
prices and inflation do not necessarily parallel one another. For example, in
1970, tickets cost \$1.55 or about \$6.68 in inflation-adjusted 2004 dollars; by
1980, prices had risen to about \$2.69, a drop to \$5.50 in inflation-adjusted
2004 dollars.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-LLU\_(2004)\_106-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-LLU\_(2004)-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Ticket prices have also risen at
different rates of inflation around the world, further complicating the process
of adjusting worldwide grosses.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
Bialik\_(2010-1-29)\_104-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-Bialik\_(2010-1-29)-104"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Another complication is release in multiple formats for which different
ticket prices are charged. One notable example of this phenomenon is
<i>Avatar</i>, which was also released in <a href="/wiki/3D\_film" title="3D
film">3D</a> and <a href="/wiki/IMAX" title="IMAX">IMAX</a>: almost two-thirds
of tickets for that film were for 3D showings with an average price of \$10, and
about one-sixth were for IMAX showings with an average price over \$14.50,
compared to a 2010 average price of \$7.61 for 2D films.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-Gray\_(2010-02-03)\_107-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Gray\_(2010-02-03)-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> Social and economic factors such as population
change<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Bialik\_(2010-1-30)\_108-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Bialik\_(2010-1-30)-108"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the growth
of international markets<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Kolesnikov-
Jessop\_109-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Kolesnikov-Jessop-109"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Hoad\_110-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Hoad-110"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Frankel\_111-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Frankel-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> also have an effect on the number of people
purchasing theater tickets, along with audience demographics where some films
sell a much higher proportion of discounted children's tickets, or perform
better in big cities where tickets cost more.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-Pincus-Roth\_(2009)\_105-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-Pincus-
Roth\_(2009)-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The measuring system for gauging a film's success is based on unadjusted
grosses, mainly because historically this is the way it has always been done
because of the practices of the film industry: the box-office receipts are
compiled by theaters and relayed to the distributor, which in turn releases them
to the media.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Bialik\_(2007)\_112-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Bialik\_(2007)-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Converting to a more representative
system that counts ticket sales rather than gross is also fraught with problems
because the only data available for older films are the sale totals.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Bialik\_(2010-1-30)\_108-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Bialik\_(2010-1-30)-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> As the motion picture industry is highly oriented
towards marketing currently released films, unadjusted figures are always used
in marketing campaigns so that new blockbuster films can much more easily
achieve a high sales ranking, and thus be promoted as a "top film of all
time",<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-LLU\_(2004)\_106-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-
LLU\_(2004)-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
Leonhardt\_113-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Leonhardt-113"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> so there is
little incentive to switch to a more robust analysis from a marketing or even
newsworthy point of view.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
Bialik\_(2007)\_112-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-Bialik\_(2007)-112"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Despite the inherent difficulties in accounting for inflation, several
attempts have been made. Estimates depend on the <a href="/wiki/Price\_index"
title="Price index">price index</a> used to adjust the grosses,<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Leonhardt\_113-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Leonhardt-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Exchange\_rate"
title="Exchange rate">exchange rates</a> used to convert between currencies can
also affect the calculations, both of which can have an effect on the ultimate
rankings of an inflation adjusted list. <i>Gone with the Wind</i>—first released
in 1939—is generally considered to be the most successful film, with <i><a
href="/wiki/Guinness\_World\_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness
World Records</a></i> in 2014 estimating its adjusted global gross at
\$3.4 billion. Estimates for <i>Gone with the Wind</i><span class="nowrap"
style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s adjusted gross have varied substantially:
its owner, <a href="/wiki/Turner\_Entertainment" title="Turner
Entertainment">Turner Entertainment</a>, estimated its adjusted earnings at
\$3.3 billion in 2007, a few years earlier than the <i>Guinness</i> estimate;<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-gwtw\_tcm\_114-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
gwtw\_tcm-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> other estimates fall either side of this amount,
with one putting its gross just under \$3 billion in 2010,<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-Shone\_115-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Shone-115"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while another
provided an alternative figure of \$3.8 billion in 2006.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-116"><a href="\#cite\_note-116"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Which film is
<i>Gone with the Wind</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-
left:0.1em;">'</span>s nearest rival depends on the set of figures used:
<i>Guinness</i> had <i>Avatar</i> in second place with \$3 billion, while other
estimates saw <i>Titanic</i> in the runner-up spot with first-run worldwide
earnings of almost \$2.9 billion at 2010 prices.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-Shone\_115-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-Shone-115"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="High-grossing\_films\_by\_year">High-
grossing films by year</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1224211176">.mw-parser-output
.quotebox\{background-color:\#F9F9F9;border:1px solid \#aaa;box-sizing:border-
box;padding:10px;font-size:88\%;max-width:100\%\}.mw-parser-output

<div class="quotebox-title" style="color: \#202122;background-color:
\#F0EAD6;;"><span class="anchor" id="distributor\_rental"></span>Glossary: <a
class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theatrical\_rental" title="Theatrical
rental">Distributor rentals</a></div>
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>Box-office figures are reported in either gross revenue or <i>distributor
rentals</i>, the latter being especially true of older films. Commonly mistaken
for home video revenue, distributor rentals are the distributor's share of the
film's theatrical revenue (i.e. the box office gross less the exhibitor's
cut).<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Cones\_125-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Cones-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Marich\_126-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Marich-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Historically, the rental price averaged
at 30–40\% when the distributors owned the theater chains, equating to just over
a third of the gross being paid to the distributor of the film.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Balio\_127-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Balio-127"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In
the modern marketplace, rental fees can vary greatly—depending on a number of
factors—although the films from the major studios average out at 43\%.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Cones\_125-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-Cones-125"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
</blockquote>
</div>
<p>Audience tastes were fairly eclectic during the 20th century, but several
trends did emerge. During the <a href="/wiki/Silent\_film" title="Silent
film">silent era</a>, films with <a href="/wiki/War\_film" title="War film">war
themes</a> were popular with audiences, with <i><a
href="/wiki/The\_Birth\_of\_a\_Nation" title="The Birth of a Nation">The Birth of a
Nation</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/American\_Civil\_War" title="American Civil
War">American Civil War</a>), <i><a
href="/wiki/The\_Four\_Horsemen\_of\_the\_Apocalypse\_(1921\_film)" title="The Four
Horsemen of the Apocalypse (1921 film)">The Four Horsemen of the
Apocalypse</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The\_Big\_Parade" title="The Big Parade">The
Big Parade</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Wings\_(1927\_film)" title="Wings (1927
film)">Wings</a></i> (all <a href="/wiki/World\_War\_I" title="World War I">World
War I</a>) becoming the most successful films in their respective years of
release, with the trend coming to an end with <i><a
href="/wiki/All\_Quiet\_on\_the\_Western\_Front\_(1930\_film)" title="All Quiet on the
Western Front (1930 film)">All Quiet on the Western Front</a></i> in 1930. With
the advent of <a href="/wiki/Sound\_film" title="Sound film">sound</a> in 1927,
the <a href="/wiki/Musical\_film" title="Musical film">musical</a>—the genre best
placed to showcase the new technology—took over as the most popular type of film
with audiences, with 1928 and 1929 both being topped by musical films. The genre
continued to perform strongly in the 1930s, but the outbreak of <a
href="/wiki/World\_War\_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> saw war-themed
films dominate again during this period, starting with <i>Gone with the Wind</i>
(American Civil War) in 1939, and finishing with <i><a
href="/wiki/The\_Best\_Years\_of\_Our\_Lives" title="The Best Years of Our Lives">The
Best Years of Our Lives</a></i> (World War II) in 1946. <i><a
href="/wiki/Samson\_and\_Delilah\_(1949\_film)" title="Samson and Delilah (1949
film)">Samson and Delilah</a></i> (1949) saw the beginning of a trend of
increasingly expensive <a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/List\_of\_historical\_drama\_films" title="List of historical drama
films">historical dramas</a> set during <a href="/wiki/Ancient\_Rome"
title="Ancient Rome">Ancient Rome</a>/<a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/Biblical\_times" title="Biblical times">biblical times</a> throughout
the 1950s as cinema competed with television for audiences,<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-128"><a href="\#cite\_note-128"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with <i><a
href="/wiki/Quo\_Vadis\_(1951\_film)" title="Quo Vadis (1951 film)">Quo
Vadis</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The\_Robe\_(film)" title="The Robe (film)">The
Robe</a></i>, <i>The Ten Commandments</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ben-
Hur\_(1959\_film)" title="Ben-Hur (1959 film)">Ben-Hur</a></i> and <i><a
href="/wiki/Spartacus\_(film)" title="Spartacus (film)">Spartacus</a></i> all
becoming the highest-grossing film of the year during initial release, before
the genre started to wane after several high-profile failures.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-HallNeale179\_129-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
HallNeale179-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> The success of <i><a
href="/wiki/White\_Christmas\_(film)" title="White Christmas (film)">White
Christmas</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/South\_Pacific\_(1958\_film)" title="South
Pacific (1958 film)">South Pacific</a></i> in the 1950s foreshadowed the
comeback of the musical in the 1960s with <i><a
href="/wiki/West\_Side\_Story\_(1961\_film)" title="West Side Story (1961
film)">West Side Story</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Mary\_Poppins\_(film)"
title="Mary Poppins (film)">Mary Poppins</a></i>, <i><a
href="/wiki/My\_Fair\_Lady\_(film)" title="My Fair Lady (film)">My Fair
Lady</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The\_Sound\_of\_Music\_(film)" title="The Sound of
Music (film)">The Sound of Music</a></i> and <i><a
href="/wiki/Funny\_Girl\_(film)" title="Funny Girl (film)">Funny Girl</a></i> all
among the top films of the decade. The 1970s saw a shift in audience tastes to
<a href="/wiki/High\_concept" title="High concept">high concept</a> films, with
six such films made by either <a href="/wiki/George\_Lucas" title="George
Lucas">George Lucas</a> or <a href="/wiki/Steven\_Spielberg" title="Steven
Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a> topping the chart during the 1980s. The 21st
century has seen an increasing dependence on franchises and <a
href="/wiki/Film\_adaptation" title="Film adaptation">adaptations</a>, with the
box-office dominance of films based on pre-existing intellectual property at
record levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-130"><a
href="\#cite\_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a
class="mw-file-description"
href="/wiki/File:Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg"><img alt="A portrait of
a bespectacled middle aged man." class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="3248"
data-file-width="2416" decoding="async" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org
/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg/170px-
Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/
commons/thumb/6/67/Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg/255px-
Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/com
mons/thumb/6/67/Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg/340px-
Steven\_Spielberg\_by\_Gage\_Skidmore.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a><figcaption>Films
directed by Steven Spielberg have been the highest-grossing film of the year on
six occasions, and on three occasions have been the highest-grossing film of all
time.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Steven Spielberg is the most represented director on the chart, with six
films to his credit, occupying the top spot in 1975, 1981, 1982, 1984, 1989 and
1993. <a href="/wiki/Cecil\_B.\_DeMille" title="Cecil B. DeMille">Cecil B.
DeMille</a> (1932, 1947, 1949, 1952 and 1956) is in second place with five films
and <a href="/wiki/William\_Wyler" title="William Wyler">William Wyler</a> (1942,
1946, 1959 and 1968) and <a href="/wiki/James\_Cameron" title="James
Cameron">James Cameron</a> (1991, 1997, 2009 and 2022) are tied for third place
with four films. <a href="/wiki/D.\_W.\_Griffith" title="D. W. Griffith">D. W.
Griffith</a> (1915, 1916 and 1920), <a href="/wiki/George\_Roy\_Hill"
title="George Roy Hill">George Roy Hill</a> (1966, 1969 and 1973) and the <a
href="/wiki/Russo\_brothers" title="Russo brothers">Russo brothers</a> (2016,
2018 and 2019) all feature heavily with three films apiece. George Lucas
directed two chart-toppers in 1977 and 1999, but also served in a strong
creative capacity as a producer and writer in 1980, 1981, 1983, 1984 and 1989 as
well. The following directors have also all directed two films on the chart: <a
href="/wiki/Frank\_Lloyd" title="Frank Lloyd">Frank Lloyd</a>, <a
href="/wiki/King\_Vidor" title="King Vidor">King Vidor</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Frank\_Capra" title="Frank Capra">Frank Capra</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Michael\_Curtiz" title="Michael Curtiz">Michael Curtiz</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Leo\_McCarey" title="Leo McCarey">Leo McCarey</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Alfred\_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, <a
href="/wiki/David\_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Stanley\_Kubrick" title="Stanley Kubrick">Stanley Kubrick</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Guy\_Hamilton" title="Guy Hamilton">Guy Hamilton</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Mike\_Nichols" title="Mike Nichols">Mike Nichols</a>, <a
href="/wiki/William\_Friedkin" title="William Friedkin">William Friedkin</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Peter\_Jackson" title="Peter Jackson">Peter Jackson</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Gore\_Verbinski" title="Gore Verbinski">Gore Verbinski</a>, and <a
href="/wiki/Michael\_Bay" title="Michael Bay">Michael Bay</a>; <a
href="/wiki/Mervyn\_LeRoy" title="Mervyn LeRoy">Mervyn LeRoy</a>, <a
href="/wiki/Ken\_Annakin" title="Ken Annakin">Ken Annakin</a> and <a
href="/wiki/Robert\_Wise" title="Robert Wise">Robert Wise</a> are each
represented by one solo credit and one shared credit, and <a
href="/wiki/John\_Ford" title="John Ford">John Ford</a> co-directed two films.
Disney films are usually co-directed and some directors have served on several
winning teams: <a href="/wiki/Wilfred\_Jackson" title="Wilfred Jackson">Wilfred
Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamilton\_Luske" title="Hamilton Luske">Hamilton
Luske</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clyde\_Geronimi" title="Clyde Geronimi">Clyde
Geronimi</a>, <a href="/wiki/David\_Hand\_(animator)" title="David Hand
(animator)">David Hand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben\_Sharpsteen" title="Ben
Sharpsteen">Ben Sharpsteen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wolfgang\_Reitherman"
title="Wolfgang Reitherman">Wolfgang Reitherman</a> and Bill Roberts have all
co-directed at least two films on the list. Only seven directors have topped the
chart in consecutive years: McCarey (1944 and 1945), Nichols (1966 and 1967),
Spielberg (1981 and 1982), Jackson (2002 and 2003), Verbinski (2006 and 2007)
and the Russo brothers (2018 and 2019).
</p><p>Because of release schedules—especially in the case of films released
towards the end of the year—and different release patterns across the world,
many films can do business in two or more calendar years; therefore the grosses
documented here are not confined to just the year of release. Grosses are not
limited to original theatrical runs either, with many older films often being
re-released periodically so the figures represent all the business a film has
done since its original release; a film's first-run gross is included in
brackets after the total if known. Because of incomplete data it cannot be known
for sure how much money some films have made and when they made it, but
generally the chart chronicles the films from each year that went on to earn the
most. In the cases where estimates conflict both films are recorded, and in
cases where a film has moved into first place because of being re-released the
previous record-holder is also retained.
</p>

<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239549316" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-
style"/><div class="refbegin" style="">
<p>({\ldots}) Since grosses are not limited to original theatrical runs, a film's
first-run gross is included in brackets after the total if known.
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_USgross"><sup>*</sup>Canada and U.S. gross only.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Rentals"><sup>R</sup>Distributor rental.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote"><sup>TBA</sup>To be
ascertained.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Intolerance"><sup>IN</sup>No contemporary sources provide figures
for <i>20,000 Leagues Under the Sea</i>, although <a
href="/wiki/The\_Numbers\_(website)" title="The Numbers (website)">The Numbers</a>
provides a figure of \$8,000,000 for the North American box-office gross.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-363"><a href="\#cite\_note-363"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, it is
possible this figure has been mistaken for the gross of the 1954 remake which
also earned \$8,000,000 in North American rentals.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-Finler358\_364-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Finler358-364"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_For\_Heaven's\_Sake"><sup>FH</sup>Some sources such as The Numbers
state that <i><a href="/wiki/Aloma\_of\_the\_South\_Seas\_(1926\_film)" title="Aloma
of the South Seas (1926 film)">Aloma of the South Seas</a></i> is the highest
grossing film of the year, earning \$3 million.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-365"><a href="\#cite\_note-365"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, no
contemporary sources provide figures for <i>Aloma of the South Seas</i>, so it
is unclear what the \$3 million figure relates to. If it were the rental gross
then that would have made it not only the highest-grossing film of the year, but
one of the highest-grossing films of the silent era, and if that is the case it
would be unusual for both <i><a
href="/wiki/International\_Motion\_Picture\_Almanac" title="International Motion
Picture Almanac">International Motion Picture Almanac</a></i> and <i><a
href="/wiki/Variety\_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> to
omit it from their lists.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Sunny\_Side\_Up"><sup>SS</sup>It is not clear if the figure for
<i>Sunny Side Up</i> is for North America or worldwide. Other sources put its
earnings at \$2 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-366"><a
href="\#cite\_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> which may suggest the higher figure is the worldwide
rental, given the confusion over international figures during this period.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-HallNeale6\_367-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
HallNeale6-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_One\_Night"><sup>ON</sup>The figure for <i>It Happened One Night</i>
is not truly representative of its success: it was distributed as a package deal
along with more than two dozen other <a href="/wiki/Columbia\_Pictures"
title="Columbia Pictures">Columbia</a> films, and the total earnings were
averaged out; the true gross would have been much higher.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-368"><a href="\#cite\_note-368"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Snow\_White"><sup>S7</sup><i>Snow White</i><span class="nowrap"
style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s \$418 million global <a href="/wiki/Cume"
title="Cume">cume</a> omits earnings outside of North America from 1987
onwards.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote\_GWTW"><sup>GW</sup>It
is not absolutely clear how much <i>Gone with the Wind</i> earned from its
initial release. Contemporary accounts often list it as earning \$32 million in
North American rentals and retrospective charts have often duplicated this
claim; however, it is likely this was the worldwide rental figure. Trade
journals would collate the data by either obtaining it from the distributors
themselves, who were keen to promote a successful film, or by surveying theaters
and constructing an estimate. Distributors would often report the worldwide
rental since the higher figure made the film appear more successful, while
estimates were limited to performance in North America; therefore it was not
unusual for worldwide and North American rentals to be mixed up. Following the
outbreak of World War II, many of the foreign markets were unavailable to
Hollywood so it became standard practice to just report on North American box-
office performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-HallNeale6\_367-1"><a
href="\#cite\_note-HallNeale6-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In keeping with this new approach, the
North American rental for <i>Gone with the Wind</i> was revised to \$21 million
in 1947 (\$11 million lower than the previous figure),<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-369"><a href="\#cite\_note-369"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and as of
1953—following the 1947 re-release—<i>Variety</i> was reporting earnings of
\$26 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-370"><a
href="\#cite\_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> Through 1956, <a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/MGM" title="MGM">MGM</a> reported cumulative North American earnings
of \$30,015,000 and foreign earnings of \$18,964,000, from three releases.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-BlockWilson129\_371-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
BlockWilson129-371"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> Worldwide rentals of \$32 million from the initial
release is consistent with the revised figures and later reported worldwide
figures: they indicate that the film earned \$21 million in North America and
\$11 million overseas from the initial release, and added a further \$9 million in
North America and \$8 million overseas from subsequent re-releases up to
1956.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Mom\_and\_Dad"><sup>MD</sup><i>Mom and Dad</i> does not generally
feature in 'high-gross' lists such as those published by <i>Variety</i> due to
its independent distribution. Essentially belonging to the <a
href="/wiki/Exploitation\_film" title="Exploitation film">exploitation genre</a>,
it was marketed as an educational <a href="/wiki/Social\_guidance\_film"
title="Social guidance film">sex hygiene</a> film in an effort to circumvent <a
href="/wiki/Film\_censorship" title="Film censorship">censorship laws</a>.
Falling foul of the <a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/Motion\_Picture\_Production\_Code" title="Motion Picture Production
Code">Motion Picture Production Code</a>, <i>Mom and Dad</i> was prevented from
obtaining mainstream distribution and restricted to independent and <a
href="/wiki/Drive-in\_theater" title="Drive-in theater">drive-in theaters</a>. It
was the biggest hit of its kind, and remained in continual distribution until
the 1970s when <a href="/wiki/Hardcore\_pornography" title="Hardcore
pornography">hardcore pornography</a> eventually took over. At the end of 1947
it had earned \$2 million, and by 1949, \$8 million; by 1956 it had earned
\$22 million in rentals, representing a gross of \$80 million, and would have
easily placed in the top ten films in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Estimates
of its total earnings are as high as \$100 million.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Unconquered"><sup>UN</sup>Chopra-Gant stipulates that the figure
given for <i>Unconquered</i> is for North American box-office, but as was common
at the time, the chart confuses worldwide and North American grosses. Other
sources state that the takings for <i>Forever Amber</i> (\$8 million) and <i>Life
with Father</i> (\$6.5 million)<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-372"><a
href="\#cite\_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> were in fact worldwide rental grosses, so it is
possible this is also true of <i>Unconquered</i>.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Cinerama"><sup>CI</sup>The <a href="/wiki/Cinerama"
title="Cinerama">Cinerama</a> figures represent gross amounts. Since the
Cinerama corporation owned the theaters there were no rental fees for the films,
meaning the studio received 100\% of the box-office gross, unlike the case with
most other films where the distributor typically receives less than half the
gross. Since <i>Variety</i> at the time ranked films by their U.S. and Canadian
rental, they constructed a hypothetical rental figure for the Cinerama films to
provide a basis for comparison to other films in their chart: in the case of
<i>This Is Cinerama</i>, the \$50 million worldwide gross was reconfigured as a
\$12.5 million U.S. rental gross; this is exactly 25\% of the amount reported by
Cinerama, so <i>Variety</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-
left:0.1em;">'</span>s formula seemingly halved the gross to obtain an estimate
for the U.S. share, and halved it again to simulate a rental fee.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-373"><a href="\#cite\_note-373"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> All five
Cinerama features collectively generated \$120 million in worldwide box office
receipts.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-374"><a href="\#cite\_note-374"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Greatest\_Show"><sup>GS</sup><i>Variety</i> put the worldwide rental
for <i>The Greatest Show on Earth</i> at around \$18.35 million (with
\$12.8 million coming from the United States<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
Finler358\_364-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-Finler358-364"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>) a year after
its release; however, Birchard puts its earnings at just over \$15 million up to
1962. It is likely that Birchard's figure is just the North American gross
rental, and includes revenue from the 1954 and 1960 reissues.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_Star\_Wars"><sup>SW</sup>The "first run" <i>Star Wars</i> grosses do
not include revenue from the 1997 special-edition releases; however, the figure
does include revenue from the re-releases prior to the <a
href="/wiki/Star\_Wars\_(film)\#Special\_Edition" title="Star Wars (film)">special
editions</a>.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_HP1\_gross"><sup>HP1</sup>The <i>Harry Potter and the Philosopher's
Stone</i> reissue totals recorded by Box Office Mojo for Brazil (2020), Italy
(2021), Netherlands (2021) and South Korea (2021) have been deducted from the
lifetime gross due to Box Office Mojo double-counting the original release
grosses in those countries.</span>
</p><p><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-
inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite"
id="endnote\_HP8\_budget"><sup>HP8</sup>Production costs were shared with <i><a
href="/wiki/Harry\_Potter\_and\_the\_Deathly\_Hallows\_\%E2\%80\%93\_Part\_1" title="Harry
Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows –
Part 1</a></i>.</span>
</p>
</div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Timeline\_of\_highest-
grossing\_films">Timeline of highest-grossing films</h2></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a
class="mw-file-description"
href="/wiki/File:Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg"><img alt="The
theatrical poster for The Birth of a Nation depicting a hooded man carrying a
burning cross on horse back." class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1482"
data-file-width="961" decoding="async" height="262" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/
wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg/170px-
Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedi
a/commons/thumb/6/61/Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg/255px-
Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/c
ommons/thumb/6/61/Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg/340px-
Birth\_of\_a\_Nation\_theatrical\_poster.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a><figcaption><i>The
Birth of a Nation</i> pioneered many of the techniques used in filmmaking today,
becoming the most successful film ever made at the time of its
release.</figcaption></figure>
<p>At least eleven films have held the record of 'highest-grossing film' since
<i>The Birth of a Nation</i> assumed the top spot in 1915. Both <i>The Birth of
a Nation</i> and <i>Gone with the Wind</i> spent twenty-five consecutive years
apiece as the highest-grosser, with films directed by Steven Spielberg and James
Cameron holding the record on three occasions each. Spielberg became the first
director to break his own record when <i>Jurassic Park</i> overtook <i>E.T.</i>,
and Cameron emulated the feat when <i>Avatar</i> broke the record set by
<i>Titanic</i>. When it took over the top spot in 2019, <i>Avengers: Endgame</i>
became the first sequel to hold the record of highest-grossing film, and in
doing so interrupted thirty-six years of Spielberg/Cameron dominance before
<i>Avatar</i> reclaimed the top spot two years later in 2021 upon a re-release.
</p><p>Some sources claim that <i>The Big Parade</i> superseded <i>The Birth of
a Nation</i> as highest-grossing film, eventually being replaced by <i>Snow
White and the Seven Dwarfs</i>, which in turn was quickly usurped by <i>Gone
with the Wind</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Dirks\_(2010)\_375-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Dirks\_(2010)-375"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Exact figures are not known for <i>The
Birth of a Nation</i>, but contemporary records put its worldwide earnings at
\$5.2 million as of 1919.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Wasko\_376-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Wasko-376"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Its international release was delayed by
World War I, and it was not released in many foreign territories until the
1920s; coupled with further re-releases in the United States, its \$10 million
earnings as reported by <i><a href="/wiki/Variety\_(magazine)" title="Variety
(magazine)">Variety</a></i> in 1932 are consistent with the earlier figure.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Variety\_(1932)\_377-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Variety\_(1932)-377"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> At this time, <i>Variety</i> still had <i>The Birth
of a Nation</i> ahead of <i>The Big Parade</i> (\$6,400,000) on distributor
rentals and—if its estimate is correct—<i>Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs</i>
(\$8,500,000)<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-378"><a
href="\#cite\_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> would not have earned enough on its first theatrical
run to take the record;<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-379"><a
href="\#cite\_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> although it would have been the highest-grossing
'talkie',<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-380"><a href="\#cite\_note-380"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
displacing <i>The Singing Fool</i> (\$5,900,000).<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-381"><a href="\#cite\_note-381"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although
received wisdom holds that it is unlikely <i>The Birth of a Nation</i> was ever
overtaken by a silent-era film,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-382"><a
href="\#cite\_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> the record would fall to 1925's <i>Ben-Hur</i>
(\$9,386,000) if <i>The Birth of a Nation</i> earned significantly less than its
estimated gross.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-HallNeale163\_383-0"><a
href="\#cite\_note-HallNeale163-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In addition to its gross rental earnings
through public exhibition, <i>The Birth of a Nation</i> played at a large number
of private, club and organizational engagements which figures are unavailable
for.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-du\_Brow\_384-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
du\_Brow-384"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> It was hugely popular with the <a
href="/wiki/Ku\_Klux\_Klan" title="Ku Klux Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a> who used it to
drive recruitment,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-385"><a
href="\#cite\_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> and at one point <i>Variety</i> estimated its total
earnings to stand at around \$50 million.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-386"><a href="\#cite\_note-386"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite later
retracting the claim, the sum has been widely reported even though it has never
been substantiated.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Wasko\_376-1"><a
href="\#cite\_note-Wasko-376"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span
class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While it is generally accepted that
<i>Gone with the Wind</i> took over the record of highest-grossing film on its
initial release—which is true in terms of public exhibition—it is likely it did
not overtake <i>The Birth of a Nation</i> in total revenue until a much later
date, with it still being reported as the highest earner up until the 1960s.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-du\_Brow\_384-1"><a href="\#cite\_note-
du\_Brow-384"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>Gone with the Wind</i> itself may have been
briefly overtaken by <i>The Ten Commandments</i> (1956), which closed at the end
of 1960 with worldwide rentals of \$58–60 million<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-387"><a href="\#cite\_note-387"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-HallNeale160\_388-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
HallNeale160-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> compared to <i>Gone with the Wind</i><span
class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s \$59 million;<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Oviatt\_(1961)\_389-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Oviatt\_(1961)-389"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> if it did claim the top spot its tenure there was
short-lived, since <i>Gone with the Wind</i> was re-released the following year
and increased its earnings to \$67 million. Depending on how accurate the
estimates are, the 1959 remake of <i>Ben-Hur</i> may also have captured the
record from <i>Gone with the Wind</i>: as of the end of 1961 it had earned
\$47 million worldwide,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-390"><a
href="\#cite\_note-390"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> and by 1963 it was trailing <i>Gone with the
Wind</i> by just \$2 million with international takings of \$65 million,<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Thomas\_(1963)\_391-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Thomas\_(1963)-391"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> ultimately earning \$66 million from its initial
release.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-392"><a href="\#cite\_note-392"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a
class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg"><img
class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2388" data-file-width="1824"
decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thum
b/d/dd/Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg/170px-Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg" srcset="//upload
.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg/255px-
Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/
dd/Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg/340px-Deep\_Throat\_poster\_2.jpg 2x"
width="170"/></a><figcaption>The 1972 pornographic film <i>Deep Throat</i>
reportedly earned as much as \$600 million, a figure that may have been inflated
by gangsters in money-laundering schemes.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Another film purported to have been the highest-grosser is the 1972 <a
href="/wiki/Pornographic\_film" title="Pornographic film">pornographic film</a>
<i><a href="/wiki/Deep\_Throat\_(film)" title="Deep Throat (film)">Deep
Throat</a></i>. In 1984, <a href="/wiki/Linda\_Lovelace" title="Linda
Lovelace">Linda Lovelace</a> testified to a <a
href="/wiki/United\_States\_Senate\_Committee\_on\_the\_Judiciary" title="United
States Senate Committee on the Judiciary">United States Senate Judiciary</a>
Subcommittee on juvenile justice that the film had earned \$600 million;<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-393"><a href="\#cite\_note-393"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> this figure has
been the subject of much speculation, since if it is accurate then the film
would have made more money than <i>Star Wars</i>, and finished the 1970s as the
highest-grossing film. The main argument against this figure is that it simply
did not have a wide enough release to sustain the sort of sums that would be
required for it to ultimately gross this amount.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-394"><a href="\#cite\_note-394"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Exact figures
are not known, but testimony in a federal trial in 1976—about four years into
the film's release—showed the film had grossed over \$25 million.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-395"><a href="\#cite\_note-395"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a
href="/wiki/Roger\_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> has reasoned it
possibly did earn as much as \$600 million on paper, since mobsters owned most of
the <a href="/wiki/Adult\_movie\_theater" title="Adult movie theater">adult movie
theaters</a> during this period and would <a href="/wiki/Money\_laundering"
title="Money laundering">launder</a> income from drugs and prostitution through
them, so probably inflated the box-office receipts for the film.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-396"><a href="\#cite\_note-396"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<p><i>The Birth of a Nation</i>, <i>Gone with the Wind</i>, <i>The
Godfather</i>, <i>Jaws</i>, <i>Star Wars</i>, <i>E.T.</i>, and <i>Avatar</i> all
increased their record grosses with re-releases. The grosses from their original
theatrical runs are included here along with totals from re-releases up to the
point that they lost the record; therefore the total for <i>The Birth of a
Nation</i> includes income from its reissues up to 1940; the total for <i>Star
Wars</i> includes revenue from the late 1970s and early 1980s reissues but not
from the 1997 Special Edition; the total for <i>E.T.</i> incorporates its gross
from the 1985 reissue but not from 2002. The total for <i>Avatar</i>'s first
appearance on the chart includes revenue from the 2010 Special Edition, which
represents all of its earnings up to the point it relinquished the record,
whereas its second appearance also incorporates revenue from a 2020 re-release
in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" title="Asia-
Pacific">Asia-Pacific</a> region as well as the 2021 re-release in China which
helped it to reclaim the record. <i>Gone with the Wind</i> is likewise
represented twice on the chart: the 1940 entry includes earnings from its
staggered 1939–1942 release (<a href="/wiki/Roadshow\_theatrical\_release"
title="Roadshow theatrical release">roadshow</a>/​<a href="/wiki/Wide\_release"
title="Wide release">general release</a>/​<a href="/wiki/Discount\_theater"
title="Discount theater">second-run</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
Bartel\_397-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-Bartel-397"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> along with all
of its revenue up to the 1961 reissue prior to losing the record to <i>The Sound
of Music</i> in 1966; its 1971 entry—after it took back the record—includes
income from the 1967 and 1971 reissues but omitting later releases. <i>The
Godfather</i> was re-released in 1973 after its success at the <a
href="/wiki/45th\_Academy\_Awards" title="45th Academy Awards">45th Academy
Awards</a>, and <i>Jaws</i> was released again in 1976, and their grosses here
most likely include earnings from those releases. <i>The Sound of Music</i>,
<i>The Godfather</i>, <i>Jaws</i>, <i>Jurassic Park</i>, and <i>Titanic</i> have
all increased their earnings with further releases, but they are not included in
the totals here because they had already conceded the record prior to being re-
released.</p><div class="" style="clear:both;"></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Highest-
grossing\_franchises\_and\_film\_series">Highest-grossing franchises and film
series</h2></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-
style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a
href="/wiki/List\_of\_highest-grossing\_media\_franchises" title="List of highest-
grossing media franchises">List of highest-grossing media franchises</a></div>
<p>Prior to 2000, only seven <a href="/wiki/Film\_series" title="Film
series">film series</a> had grossed over \$1 billion at the box office: <i><a
href="/wiki/List\_of\_James\_Bond\_films" title="List of James Bond films">James
Bond</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-415"><a
href="\#cite\_note-415"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/List\_of\_Star\_Wars\_films"
title="List of Star Wars films">Star Wars</a></i>,<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-416"><a href="\#cite\_note-416"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a
href="/wiki/Indiana\_Jones" title="Indiana Jones">Indiana Jones</a></i>,<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-417"><a href="\#cite\_note-417"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a
class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rocky\_(film\_series)" title="Rocky (film
series)">Rocky</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-418"><a
href="\#cite\_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-419"><a
href="\#cite\_note-419"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-420"><a
href="\#cite\_note-420"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Batman\_in\_film" title="Batman in
film">Batman</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-421"><a
href="\#cite\_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Jurassic\_Park" title="Jurassic
Park">Jurassic Park</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-422"><a
href="\#cite\_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/List\_of\_Star\_Trek\_films"
title="List of Star Trek films">Star Trek</a></i>.<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-423"><a href="\#cite\_note-423"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since the turn
of the century, that number has increased to over a hundred.<sup
class="reference" id="cite\_ref-Numbers\_franchises\_424-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-
Numbers\_franchises-424"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> This is partly due to inflation and market growth,
but it is also due to Hollywood's adoption of the <a
href="/wiki/Media\_franchise" title="Media franchise">franchise</a> model: films
that have built-in brand recognition such as being based on a well-known
literary source or an established character. The methodology is based on the
concept that films associated with things audiences are already familiar with
can be more effectively marketed to them, and as such are known as "pre-sold"
films within the industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-
economist\_425-0"><a href="\#cite\_note-economist-425"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A franchise is typically defined to be at least two works derived from a
common <a href="/wiki/Intellectual\_property" title="Intellectual
property">intellectual property</a>. Traditionally, the work has a tautological
relationship with the property, but this is not a prerequisite. An enduring
staple of the franchise model is the concept of the <i><a
href="/wiki/Crossover\_(fiction)" title="Crossover (fiction)">crossover</a></i>,
which can be defined as "a story in which characters or concepts from two or
more discrete texts or series of texts meet".<sup class="reference"
id="cite\_ref-426"><a href="\#cite\_note-426"><span class="cite-
bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A consequence
of a crossover is that an intellectual property may be utilized by more than one
franchise. For example, <i><a href="/wiki/Batman\_v\_Superman:\_Dawn\_of\_Justice"
title="Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice">Batman v Superman: Dawn of
Justice</a></i> belongs to not only the <a href="/wiki/Batman"
title="Batman">Batman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Superman"
title="Superman">Superman</a> franchises, but also to the <a
href="/wiki/DC\_Extended\_Universe" title="DC Extended Universe">DC Extended
Universe</a>, which is a <i><a href="/wiki/Shared\_universe" title="Shared
universe">shared universe</a></i>. A shared universe is a particular type of
crossover where a number of characters from a wide range of fictional works wind
up sharing a fictional world.<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-427"><a
href="\#cite\_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-
bracket">]</span></a></sup> The most successful shared universe in the medium of
film is the <a href="/wiki/Marvel\_Cinematic\_Universe" title="Marvel Cinematic
Universe">Marvel Cinematic Universe</a>, a crossover between multiple superhero
properties owned by <a href="/wiki/Marvel\_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">Marvel
Comics</a>. The Marvel Cinematic Universe is also the highest-grossing
franchise, amassing over \$31 billion at the box office.
</p><p>The <i>Spider-Man</i> films are the highest-grossing series based on a
single property, earning over \$10.6 billion at the box office (although the <a
href="/wiki/Eon\_Productions" title="Eon Productions">Eon</a> <i>James Bond</i>
films have earned over \$19 billion in total when adjusted to current
prices).<sup class="reference" id="cite\_ref-429"><a href="\#cite\_note-429"><span
class="cite-bracket">[</span>a<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The
Marvel Cinematic Universe has had the most films gross over \$1 billion, with
eleven. The four <i><a href="/wiki/Avengers\_(comics)\_in\_other\_media\#Live\_action"
title="Avengers (comics) in other media">Avengers</a></i> films, the two <i><a
href="/wiki/Frozen\_(franchise)" title="Frozen (franchise)">Frozen</a></i> films,
and the two <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar\_(franchise)" title="Avatar
(franchise)">Avatar</a></i> films are the only franchises where each installment
has grossed over \$1 billion, although the <i>Jurassic Park</i>, <i><a class="mw-
redirect" href="/wiki/Black\_Panther\_(film\_series)" title="Black Panther (film
series)">Black Panther</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Inside\_Out\_(franchise)"
title="Inside Out (franchise)">Inside Out</a></i> series  have averaged over
\$1 billion per film.
</p>

<q>Distributor rentals: It is also important to know and recognize the
difference between the distributor's gross receipts and the gross rentals. The
term "rentals" refers to the aggregate amount of the film distributor's share of
monies paid at theatre box offices computed on the basis of negotiated
agreements between the distributor and the exhibitor. Note that gross receipts
refers to amounts actually received and from all markets and media, whereas
gross rentals refers to amounts earned from theatrical exhibition only,
regardless of whether received by the distributor. Thus, gross receipts is the
much broader term and includes distributor rentals. The issue of film rentals
(i.e., what percentage of a film's box office gross comes back to the
distributor) is of key importance{\ldots}More current numbers suggest that
distributor rentals for the major studio/distributor released films average in
the neighborhood of 43\% of box office gross. Again, however, such an average is
based on widely divergent distributor rental ratios on individual
films.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx\_ver=Z39.88-

<li id="cite\_note-HallNeale179-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a

text"><a href="\#CITEREFHallNeale2010">Hall \&amp; Neale 2010</a>, p. <a

href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jhvrSwOOsRgC\&amp;pg=PA179"
rel="nofollow">179</a>. "Later epics proved far more disastrous for the backers.
<a href="/wiki/Samuel\_Bronston" title="Samuel Bronston">Samuel Bronston</a>'s
<i><a href="/wiki/The\_Fall\_of\_the\_Roman\_Empire\_(film)" title="The Fall of the
Roman Empire (film)">The Fall of the Roman Empire</a></i>, filmed in Spain, cost
\$17,816,876 and grossed only \$1.9 million in America. George Stevens's long-
gestating life of Christ, <i><a href="/wiki/The\_Greatest\_Story\_Ever\_Told"
title="The Greatest Story Ever Told">The Greatest Story Ever Told</a></i>
(1965), which had been in planning since 1954 and in production since 1962,
earned domestic rentals of \$6,962,715 on a \$21,481,745 negative cost, the
largest amount yet spent on a production made entirely within the United States.
<i><a href="/wiki/The\_Bible:\_In\_the\_Beginning{\ldots}" title="The Bible: In the
Beginning{\ldots}">The Bible: In the Beginning{\ldots}</a></i> (1966) was financed by the
Italian producer <a href="/wiki/Dino\_De\_Laurentiis" title="Dino De
Laurentiis">Dino De Laurentiis</a> from private investors and Swiss banks. He
then sold distribution rights outside Italy jointly to <a class="mw-redirect"
href="/wiki/Twentieth\_Century\_Fox" title="Twentieth Century Fox">Fox</a> and <a
href="/wiki/Seven\_Arts\_Productions" title="Seven Arts Productions">Seven
Arts</a> for \$15 million (70 percent of which came from Fox), thereby recouping
the bulk of his \$18 million investment. Although <i>The Bible</i> returned a
respectable world rental of \$25.3 million, Fox was still left with a net loss of
just over \$1.5 million. It was the last biblical epic to be released by any
major Hollywood studio for nearly twenty years."</span>

<li id="cite\_note-HallNeale6-367"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\^{} <a
