class="reference-text"><a href="\#CITEREFHallNeale2010">Hall \&amp; Neale
2010</a>, pp. <a class="external text"
href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Ro0hASPfC68C\&amp;pg=PA6"
rel="nofollow">6</a>–<a class="external text"
href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Ro0hASPfC68C\&amp;pg=PA7"
rel="nofollow">7</a>. "For similar reasons of accountability, <i>Variety</i> has
typically used figures for domestic (U.S. and Canadian) rather than worldwide
revenue. This became its standard policy in 1940, when the advent of war in
Europe persuaded the American film industry (temporarily, as it turned out) that
it should be wholly reliant on the home market for profitability. Where specific
rentals data are reported in <i>Variety</i> before this (which tended to be only
sporadically) they were often for worldwide rather domestic performance. This
was also the case with other trade sources, such as <i>Quigley</i><span
class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s annual <i>Motion Picture
Almanac</i>, which published its own all-time hits lists from the early 1930s
onward. The subsequent confusion of domestic and worldwide figures, and of
rental and box-office figures, has plagued many published accounts of Hollywood
history (sometimes including those in <i>Variety</i> itself), and we have
attempted to be diligant in clarifying the differences between them."</span>
</li>

rel="nofollow"><i>A Song in the Dark: The Birth of the Musical Film</i></a>. <a
href="/wiki/Oxford\_University\_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford
University Press</a>. p. <a class="external text"
href="https://archive.org/details/songindarkbirtho00barr/page/49"
rel="nofollow">49</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN\_(identifier)"
title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a
href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-508811-3"
title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-508811-3"><bdi>978-0-19-508811-3</bdi></a>.
<q>Since it's rarely seen today, <i>The Singing Fool</i> is frequently confused
with <i>The Jazz Singer</i>; although besides Jolson and a pervasively maudlin
air the two have little in common. In the earlier film Jolson was inordinately
attached to his mother and sang "Mammy"; here the fixation was on his young son,
and "Sonny Boy" became an enormous hit. So did the film, which amassed a
stunning world-wide gross of \$5.9 million{\ldots}Some sources give it as the highest
gross of <i>any</i> film in its initial release prior to <i>Gone with the
Wind</i>. This is probably overstating it—MGM's records show that <i>Ben-Hur</i>
and <i>The Big Parade</i> grossed more, and no one knows just how much <i>The
Birth of a Nation</i> brought in. Still, by the standards of the time it's an
amazing amount.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx\_ver=Z39.88-
2004\&amp;rft\_val\_fmt=info\%3Aofi\%2Ffmt\%3Akev\%3Amtx\%3Abook\&amp;rft.genre=book\&amp;
rft.btitle=A+Song+in+the+Dark\%3A+The+Birth+of+the+Musical+Film\&amp;rft.pages=49\&
amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press\&amp;rft.date=1995\&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-
508811-
3\&amp;rft.aulast=Barrios\&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard\&amp;rft\_id=https\%3A\%2F\%2Farchiv
e.org\%2Fdetails\%2Fsongindarkbirtho00barr\%2Fpage\%2F49\&amp;rfr\_id=info\%3Asid\%2Fen.
wikipedia.org\%3AList+of+highest-grossing+films"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite\_note-382"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a
href="\#cite\_ref-382">\^{}</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link
href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-
style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEverson1998">Everson, William
K. (1998) [First published 1978]. <a class="external text"
href="https://archive.org/details/americansilentfi00ever\_0/page/374"
rel="nofollow"><i>American silent film</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Da\_Capo\_Press"
title="Da Capo Press">Da Capo Press</a>. p. <a class="external text"
href="https://books.google.com/books?id=pyQaKxBjjzMC\&amp;pg=PA374"
rel="nofollow">374</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN\_(identifier)"
title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a
href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-306-80876-0"
title="Special:BookSources/978-0-306-80876-0"><bdi>978-0-306-80876-0</bdi></a>.
<q>Putting <i>The Birth of a Nation</i> in fifth place is open to question,
since it is generally conceded to be the top-grossing film of all time. However,
it has always been difficult to obtain reliable box-office figures for this
film, and it may have been even more difficult in the mid-1930s. After listing
it until the mid-1970s as <i>the</i> top-grosser, though finding it impossible
to quote exact figures, <i>Variety</i>, the trade journal, suddenly repudiated
the claim but without giving specific details or reasons. On the basis of the
number of paid admissions, and <i>continuous</i> exhibition, its number one
position seems justified.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx\_ver=Z39.88-
2004\&amp;rft\_val\_fmt=info\%3Aofi\%2Ffmt\%3Akev\%3Amtx\%3Abook\&amp;rft.genre=book\&amp;
rft.btitle=American+silent+film\&amp;rft.pages=374\&amp;rft.pub=Da+Capo+Press\&amp;

theaters. Griffith had originally placed the potential film rental at \$3,000,000

percent of domestic returns, the film would have lost money. In a turnaround,
the foreign gross was almost double the \$1,000,000 domestic take to reach total
world rentals of \$3,000,000 and Fox's largest profit of the year at
\$664,000."</li>
<li><i>State Fair</i>: p. <a class="external text"
href="https://books.google.com/books?id=zospQ7o5u0oC\&amp;pg=PA170"
rel="nofollow">170</a> . "<i>State Fair</i> did turn out to be a substantial hit
with the help of Janet Gaynor boosting Will Rogers back to the level of money-
making star. Its prestige engagements helped raked in a total \$1,208,000 in
domestic rentals. Surprisingly, in foreign countries unfamiliar with state
fairs, it still earned a respectable \$429,000. With its total rentals, the film
ended up showing a \$398,000 profit."</li></ul>
</span></li>

<q><i>Mrs Miniver</i> was a phenomenon. It was the most popular film of the year
(from any studio) in both North America and Britain, and its foreign earnings
were three times higher than those of any other MGM film released in the 1941–42
season. The production cost (\$1,344,000) was one of the highest of the season,
indicating the studio never thought of the film as a potential loss-maker. When
the film earned a worldwide gross of \$8,878,000, MGM had the highest profit
(\$4,831,000) in its history. <i>Random Harvest</i> nearly matched the success of
<i>Mrs Miniver</i> with worldwide earnings of \$8,147,000 yielding the second-
highest profit in MGM's history (\$4,384,000). <i>Random Harvest</i> was also the
most popular film of the year in Britain, where it proved to be even more
popular than Britain's most acclaimed war film, <i>In Which We
Serve</i>.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx\_ver=Z39.88-

<q>Leading the pack of postwar sex hygiene films was <i>Mom and Dad</i> (1944),
which would become not only the most successful sex hygiene film in history but
the biggest pre-1960 exploitation film of any kind. At the end of 1947, the
<i>Los Angeles Times</i> reported that <i>Mom and Dad</i> had grossed
\$2 million. By 1949 <i>Time</i> had estimated that <i>Mom and Dad</i> had taken
in \$8 million from twenty million moviegoers. And publicity issuing from <i>Mom
and Dad</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s production
company indicated that by the end of 1956 it had grossed over \$80 million
worldwide. Net rentals of around \$22 million by 1956 would easily place it in
the top ten films of the late 1940s and early 1950s had it appeared on
conventional lists. Some estimates have placed its total gross over the years at
up to \$100 million, and it was still playing drive-in dates into 1975{\ldots}The film
was made for around \$65,000 with a crew of Hollywood veterans including director
William "One Shot" Beaudine, cinematographer Marcel LePicard, and a cast that
sported old stalwarts Hardie Albright, Francis Ford, and John
Hamilton.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx\_ver=Z39.88-
2004\&amp;rft\_val\_fmt=info\%3Aofi\%2Ffmt\%3Akev\%3Amtx\%3Abook\&amp;rft.genre=book\&amp;

ion+Films\%2C+1919\%E2\%80\%931959\&amp;rft.pages=197-
199\&amp;rft.pub=Duke+University+Press\&amp;rft.date=1999\&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8223-

dia.org\%3AList+of+highest-grossing+films"></span></span>
</li>

rel="nofollow">159</a>–161
<ul><li><i>The Ten Commandments</i>: "No film did more to entrench roadshow
policy than <i>The Ten Commandments</i>. While the success of <i>This Is
Cinerama</i>, <i>The Robe</i>, and even <i>Eighty Days</i> could be attributed,
at least in part, to their respective photographic and projection formats, that
of DeMille's film (which cost a record \$13,266,491) could not{\ldots}General release
began at normal prices in 1959 and continued until the end of the following
year, when the film was temporarily withdrawn (the first of several reissues
came in 1966). The worldwide rental by this time was around \$60 million. In the
domestic market it dislodged <i>Gone with the Wind</i> from the number one
position on Variety's list of All-Time Rentals Champs. <i>GWTW</i> had hitherto
maintained its lead through several reissues (and was soon to regain it through
another in 1961)."</li>
<li><i>The Bridge on the River Kwai</i>: Columbia's Anglo-American war film
<i>The Bridge on the River Kwai</i> (1957) opened on a roadshow basis in
selected U.S. cities (including New York, Chicago, Boston, and Los Angeles) and
in London. Costing only \$2,840,000 to produce, it grossed \$30.6 million
worldwide on first release."</li></ul>

respectable world rental of \$25.3 million, Fox was still left with a net loss of

<ul><li><i>Lawrence of Arabia</i>: Columbia released the \$13.8 million
<i>Lawrence of Arabia</i> (1962), filmed in Super Panavision 70, exclusively on
a hard-ticket basis, but opened <i>Barabbas</i> (1962), <i>The Cardinal</i>
(1963), and the \$12 million Joseph Conrad adaptation <i>Lord Jim</i> (1965) as
70 mm roadshows in selected territories only."</li>
<li><i>The Longest Day</i>: "Darryl's most ambitious independent production was
<i>The Longest Day</i> (1962), a three-hour reconstruction of D-Day filmed in
black-and-white CinemaScope at a cost of \$8 million. It grossed over \$30 million
worldwide as a roadshow followed by general release, thereby helping the studio
regain stability during its period of reorganization."</li>
<li><i>Cleopatra</i>: "With top tickets set at an all-time high of
\$5.50,<i>Cleopatra</i> had amassed as much as \$20 million in such guarantees
from exhibitors even before its premiere. Fox claimed the film had cost in total
\$44 million, of which \$31,115,000 represented the direct negative cost and the
rest distribution, print and advertising expenses. (These figures excluded the
more than \$5 million spent on the production's abortive British shoot in
1960–61, prior to its relocation to Italy.) By 1966 worldwide rentals had
reached \$38,042,000 including \$23.5 million from the United States."</li></ul>
